canonical_explanation.text: The atom, once considered indivisible, is made up of three subatomic particles: electrons (discovered by J.J. Thomson), protons (discovered by Goldstein/Rutherford), and neutrons (discovered by Chadwick). Thomson proposed the plum pudding model where electrons are embedded in a sphere of positive charge. Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment led to the nuclear model: most of the atom is empty space, with a tiny dense positively charged nucleus at the centre, surrounded by electrons. Bohr improved on Rutherford's model by placing electrons in discrete energy levels (shells) around the nucleus. The maximum number of electrons in a shell is given by 2n^2. The atomic number (Z) equals the number of protons, and the mass number (A) equals the sum of protons and neutrons. Isotopes are atoms with the same atomic number but different mass numbers. Isobars are atoms with the same mass number but different atomic numbers.
rules: Electron: negatively charged (-1), mass approximately 1/1836 of a proton, discovered by J.J. Thomson.
Proton: positively charged (+1), mass approximately 1 u, present in the nucleus.
Neutron: no charge (neutral), mass approximately 1 u, discovered by Chadwick, present in the nucleus.
Thomson's model: electrons embedded in a uniform positive sphere (plum pudding model).
Rutherford's experiment: most alpha particles pass through, few deflect, very few bounce back.
Rutherford's model: tiny dense positive nucleus, electrons revolve around it, atom mostly empty space.
Bohr's model: electrons revolve in discrete energy levels (K, L, M, N shells).
Maximum electrons in shell n = 2n^2 (K=2, L=8, M=18, N=32).
Outermost shell can hold a maximum of 8 electrons.
Atomic number (Z) = number of protons = number of electrons (in neutral atom).
Mass number (A) = number of protons + number of neutrons.
Isotopes: same Z, different A (e.g., C-12 and C-14).
Isobars: same A, different Z (e.g., Ca-40 and Ar-40).
Valence electrons determine the chemical properties and valency of an element.

questions.question_text: The electron was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: The electron was discovered by J.J. Thomson in 1897 through his cathode ray tube experiments. He observed that cathode rays were streams of negatively charged particles, which he called electrons. This was the first subatomic particle to be discovered.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford discovered the nucleus and proton. Chadwick discovered the neutron. Bohr proposed the model of electron energy levels. J.J. Thomson was the scientist who discovered the electron using cathode ray experiments.

questions.question_text: The charge on a proton is:
questions.explanation_correct: A proton carries a positive charge of +1 unit (1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs). Protons are found in the nucleus of an atom. The number of protons determines the identity of the element (atomic number).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protons are positively charged particles. Electrons are negatively charged. Neutrons are neutral (no charge). The charge on a proton is equal in magnitude but opposite in sign to the charge on an electron.

questions.question_text: The neutron was discovered by:
questions.explanation_correct: The neutron was discovered by James Chadwick in 1932. Neutrons are electrically neutral particles (no charge) found in the nucleus alongside protons. They have a mass approximately equal to that of a proton (about 1 u).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thomson discovered the electron, Rutherford discovered the nucleus and proton, and Bohr proposed the planetary model with energy levels. James Chadwick discovered the neutron in 1932 by bombarding beryllium with alpha particles.

questions.question_text: Which subatomic particle has the least mass?
questions.explanation_correct: The electron has the least mass among the three subatomic particles. Its mass is approximately 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg, which is about 1/1836 of the mass of a proton. Protons and neutrons have approximately equal masses of about 1 u each.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The electron is by far the lightest subatomic particle, with a mass of about 1/1836 that of a proton or neutron. Protons and neutrons have nearly equal masses (approximately 1 u each). This is why the mass of an atom is concentrated in its nucleus.

questions.question_text: In a cathode ray tube experiment, the cathode rays travel from:
questions.explanation_correct: Cathode rays travel from cathode (negative terminal) to anode (positive terminal). Since cathode rays are streams of electrons (negatively charged), they are repelled by the cathode (negative) and attracted towards the anode (positive).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cathode rays are streams of electrons originating at the cathode (negative electrode). Being negatively charged, they move towards the anode (positive electrode). This is the fundamental principle behind Thomson's discovery of the electron.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the subatomic particles in order of discovery?
questions.explanation_correct: The order of discovery was: Electron (J.J. Thomson, 1897), Proton (Goldstein observed canal rays in 1886, Rutherford named it 'proton' in 1919), and Neutron (Chadwick, 1932). The electron was the first subatomic particle to be identified.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct chronological order is Electron (1897) → Proton (1919, named by Rutherford) → Neutron (1932). Thomson's cathode ray experiments first revealed the electron, making it the first discovered subatomic particle.

questions.question_text: The mass of an electron is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The mass of an electron is approximately 1/1836 of the mass of a hydrogen atom (or proton), which is about 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg. This is why the mass of electrons is generally neglected when calculating the mass of an atom — almost all the mass is in the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electron's mass is about 1/1836 u, making it negligibly small compared to protons and neutrons (each approximately 1 u). This is why the atomic mass is essentially determined by the number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Thomson's model of the atom is also known as the:
questions.explanation_correct: Thomson's model is called the 'plum pudding model' (or 'watermelon model'). He proposed that the atom is a uniform sphere of positive charge with electrons embedded in it, like plums in a pudding or seeds in a watermelon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The planetary model is associated with Rutherford/Bohr. The nuclear model is Rutherford's model. The shell model is Bohr's model. Thomson's model, where electrons are embedded in a positive sphere, is specifically called the plum pudding model.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment, most alpha particles:

options.text: Passed through the gold foil without deflection
Were absorbed by the gold foil

questions.explanation_correct: In Rutherford's experiment, most alpha particles passed straight through the gold foil without any deflection. This observation led to the conclusion that most of the atom is empty space, as there was nothing to obstruct the path of most alpha particles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Most alpha particles passing through undeflected was the key observation. A small fraction was deflected at various angles, and an even smaller fraction (about 1 in 20,000) bounced back. This showed the atom is mostly empty space with a tiny, dense, positive nucleus.

questions.question_text: According to Rutherford's model, the positively charged part of the atom is called the:
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford named the positively charged centre of the atom the 'nucleus'. He concluded that it is very small compared to the overall size of the atom, is extremely dense, and contains all the positive charge and most of the mass of the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shells and orbits refer to paths of electrons. Electron cloud is a concept from quantum mechanics. Rutherford called the tiny, dense, positively charged centre of the atom the nucleus, where protons (and later, neutrons) are located.

questions.question_text: In Rutherford's experiment, the alpha particles that bounced back at 180° did so because:

options.text: They hit the dense, positively charged nucleus head-on
They were attracted by the gold atoms
The gold foil was too thick

questions.explanation_correct: The very few alpha particles that bounced back at nearly 180° did so because they collided head-on with the tiny, dense, positively charged nucleus. The strong repulsive force between the positive alpha particle and the positive nucleus reversed their direction completely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons are too light to deflect the much heavier alpha particles. The bounce-back occurred due to a head-on collision with the dense, positively charged nucleus. The repulsion between the positive alpha particle and positive nucleus caused the complete reversal of direction.

questions.question_text: A major limitation of Rutherford's model was that it could not explain:

options.text: Why the atom is electrically neutral
Why electrons do not fall into the nucleus despite being attracted to it
The positive charge of the nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford's model had a major limitation: it could not explain the stability of the atom. According to electromagnetic theory, a revolving charged particle (electron) should continuously emit energy and spiral into the nucleus. Rutherford's model had no explanation for why this does not happen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford's model successfully explained the positive nucleus and neutral atom. However, it failed to explain why electrons revolving around the nucleus do not lose energy and spiral inward. According to classical physics, an accelerating charge should radiate energy and collapse — this was the instability problem.

questions.question_text: Which observation from Rutherford's experiment proved that the nucleus is very small compared to the atom?

options.text: Most alpha particles passed through undeflected

questions.explanation_correct: The fact that most alpha particles passed through the gold foil undeflected proved that the nucleus occupies a very small space within the atom. Since the vast majority of alpha particles encountered no obstruction, most of the atom must be empty space, with the nucleus being extremely tiny.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all alpha particles bounced back — only about 1 in 20,000 did. The key observation was that MOST passed through undeflected, proving the atom is mostly empty space and the nucleus is extremely small relative to the atom's total volume.

questions.question_text: Which model of the atom was disproved by Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment?
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford's experiment disproved Thomson's plum pudding model. Thomson proposed that positive charge is uniformly distributed throughout the atom. If this were true, alpha particles would not bounce back — they would pass through easily. The bouncing back of some particles proved that positive charge is concentrated in a tiny nucleus, not spread out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford's experiment specifically disproved Thomson's model. If positive charge were spread uniformly (as Thomson proposed), no alpha particles would bounce back. The fact that some did proved the positive charge is concentrated in a tiny nucleus, contradicting Thomson's model.

questions.question_text: According to Bohr's model, electrons revolve around the nucleus in:
questions.explanation_correct: Bohr proposed that electrons revolve around the nucleus in certain fixed, discrete energy levels called shells or orbits. These shells are designated as K, L, M, N (or 1, 2, 3, 4). Electrons in these shells do not radiate energy — they only gain or lose energy when jumping between shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bohr's key contribution was that electrons are NOT in random paths but in fixed energy levels (shells). These are labelled K, L, M, N from innermost to outermost. This model resolved the stability problem of Rutherford's model by restricting electrons to specific orbits.

questions.question_text: The maximum number of electrons that can be accommodated in the second shell (L shell) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum number of electrons in any shell is given by the formula 2n², where n is the shell number. For the L shell (n = 2): 2(2)² = 2 × 4 = 8 electrons. So the L shell can hold a maximum of 8 electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula 2n²: K shell (n=1) = 2, L shell (n=2) = 8, M shell (n=3) = 18, N shell (n=4) = 32. The L shell (second shell) can accommodate a maximum of 8 electrons.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of sodium (atomic number 11) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Sodium has 11 electrons. They are distributed as follows: K shell = 2 (maximum for n=1), L shell = 8 (maximum for n=2), M shell = 1 (remaining). So the electronic configuration is 2, 8, 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons fill shells from innermost to outermost, with each shell holding up to 2n² electrons. For 11 electrons: K shell gets 2, L shell gets 8, and the remaining 1 goes to the M shell. The configuration is 2, 8, 1.

questions.question_text: An element has electronic configuration 2, 8, 7. Its valency is:
questions.explanation_correct: The element has 7 electrons in its outermost shell. Since 7 is close to 8 (the maximum for the outermost shell), this element tends to gain 1 electron to achieve a stable configuration. Therefore, its valency is 8 - 7 = 1. This element is chlorine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the outermost shell has more than 4 electrons, the valency is calculated as 8 minus the number of valence electrons. With 7 valence electrons: valency = 8 - 7 = 1. The element will gain 1 electron rather than lose 7, as gaining 1 is energetically more favourable.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of calcium (atomic number 20) is:
questions.explanation_correct: Calcium has 20 electrons. Distribution: K = 2, L = 8, M = 8 (note: the outermost shell can hold a maximum of 8 electrons, even though M shell can theoretically hold 18), N = 2. So the configuration is 2, 8, 8, 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For calcium (20 electrons): K shell = 2, L shell = 8, M shell = 8 (the outermost shell or the penultimate shell should not exceed 8 until the next shell starts filling), N shell = 2. The correct configuration is 2, 8, 8, 2.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements has the same number of valence electrons as silicon (atomic number 14)?
questions.explanation_correct: Silicon (14): configuration 2, 8, 4 — has 4 valence electrons. Carbon (6): configuration 2, 4 — also has 4 valence electrons. Both silicon and carbon have 4 electrons in their outermost shell, so they share the same valency of 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silicon has configuration 2, 8, 4 with 4 valence electrons. Sodium (2, 8, 1) has 1, aluminium (2, 8, 3) has 3, and oxygen (2, 6) has 6. Only carbon (2, 4) has 4 valence electrons, matching silicon.

questions.question_text: An element has atomic number 17. How many electrons are present in its M shell?
questions.explanation_correct: Atomic number 17 means 17 electrons. Distribution: K = 2, L = 8, M = 7. The M shell (third shell) has 7 electrons. This element is chlorine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With 17 electrons: K shell holds 2, L shell holds 8 (2 + 8 = 10 electrons placed), and the remaining 17 - 10 = 7 electrons go into the M shell. So the M shell has 7 electrons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following electronic configurations represents a noble gas?
questions.explanation_correct: The configuration 2, 8 represents neon (atomic number 10), which is a noble gas. Noble gases have completely filled outermost shells (2 for helium, 8 for all others), making them very stable and chemically inert.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases have completely filled outermost shells. 2, 8, 1 is sodium (reactive metal). 2, 8, 7 is chlorine (reactive non-metal). 2, 8, 2 is magnesium (reactive metal). Only 2, 8 represents neon, a noble gas with a complete octet in its outermost shell.

questions.question_text: The atomic number of an element is equal to:
questions.explanation_correct: The atomic number (Z) of an element equals the number of protons in the nucleus of its atom. In a neutral atom, the number of protons also equals the number of electrons. The atomic number uniquely identifies an element.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The atomic number (Z) = number of protons, not neutrons. The mass number (A) = protons + neutrons. The number of neutrons = A - Z. The atomic number defines the element — all atoms with the same number of protons belong to the same element.

questions.question_text: The mass number of an atom is the sum of:
questions.explanation_correct: The mass number (A) is the sum of the number of protons and neutrons in the nucleus of an atom. Electrons are not included because their mass is negligible (about 1/1836 of a proton). A = Z (protons) + N (neutrons).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mass number = protons + neutrons. Electrons are excluded because their mass is negligibly small compared to protons and neutrons. Since protons and neutrons each have a mass of approximately 1 u, the mass number approximately equals the atomic mass.

questions.question_text: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have:

options.text: Same mass number but different atomic numbers
Same atomic number but different mass numbers
Different atomic numbers and different mass numbers

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have the same atomic number (same number of protons) but different mass numbers (different number of neutrons). For example, hydrogen has three isotopes: protium (H-1), deuterium (H-2), and tritium (H-3).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes have the same atomic number (Z) — meaning they are the same element with the same number of protons — but different mass numbers (A) due to different numbers of neutrons. Atoms with the same mass number but different atomic numbers are called isobars, not isotopes.

questions.question_text: An atom has 11 protons and 12 neutrons. Its mass number is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mass number (A) = number of protons + number of neutrons = 11 + 12 = 23. This atom is sodium-23, the most common isotope of sodium, with atomic number 11 and mass number 23.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mass number = protons + neutrons = 11 + 12 = 23. The atomic number would be 11 (number of protons). The number 12 is just the neutron count. The mass number represents the total number of nucleons (protons + neutrons) in the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 are isotopes. The number of neutrons in Carbon-14 is:
questions.explanation_correct: Carbon has atomic number 6 (6 protons). For Carbon-14: mass number = 14. Number of neutrons = mass number - atomic number = 14 - 6 = 8. Carbon-12 has 6 neutrons, while Carbon-14 has 8 neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutrons = mass number - atomic number = 14 - 6 = 8. Both Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 have 6 protons (same element), but Carbon-14 has 8 neutrons while Carbon-12 has only 6 neutrons. The extra neutrons give Carbon-14 its higher mass number.

questions.question_text: Which pair represents isobars?
questions.explanation_correct: Calcium-40 (atomic number 20) and Argon-40 (atomic number 18) are isobars because they have the same mass number (40) but different atomic numbers. Isobars are atoms of DIFFERENT elements with the same mass number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Carbon-12 and Carbon-14 are isotopes (same element, different mass). Oxygen-16 and Oxygen-18 are also isotopes. Hydrogen-1 and Helium-4 have different mass numbers. Only Calcium-40 and Argon-40 are isobars — different elements with the same mass number (40).

questions.question_text: The number of neutrons in an atom of chlorine-37 is: (Atomic number of Cl = 17)
questions.explanation_correct: Number of neutrons = mass number - atomic number = 37 - 17 = 20. Chlorine-37 has 17 protons, 20 neutrons, and 17 electrons (in a neutral atom). The other common isotope, Chlorine-35, has 18 neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutrons = A - Z = 37 - 17 = 20. The mass number (37) includes both protons and neutrons. Subtracting the atomic number (17 protons) gives the number of neutrons (20).

questions.question_text: Isotopes of an element have identical:
questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes have identical chemical properties because they have the same number of electrons (same electronic configuration) and hence react the same way. However, their physical properties (like mass, density, and rate of diffusion) differ because they have different numbers of neutrons and different masses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes have the same atomic number but different mass numbers, so they have different numbers of neutrons and different physical properties. However, their chemical properties are identical because chemical behaviour depends on the electron configuration, which is the same for all isotopes of an element.

questions.question_text: Tritium is an isotope of hydrogen with mass number 3. How many neutrons does tritium have?
questions.explanation_correct: Hydrogen has atomic number 1 (1 proton). Tritium has mass number 3. Number of neutrons = 3 - 1 = 2. Tritium has 1 proton and 2 neutrons, making it the heaviest isotope of hydrogen. Protium has 0 neutrons and deuterium has 1 neutron.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutrons = mass number - atomic number = 3 - 1 = 2. Tritium (H-3) is the hydrogen isotope with 2 neutrons. Compare: Protium (H-1) has 0 neutrons, Deuterium (H-2) has 1 neutron, and Tritium (H-3) has 2 neutrons.

questions.question_text: The element with electronic configuration 2, 8, 3 would likely form an ion with a charge of:
questions.explanation_correct: The element has 3 valence electrons. To achieve a stable noble gas configuration (2, 8), it would lose 3 electrons, forming a +3 ion. This element is aluminium (Al), which forms the Al³⁺ ion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With 3 electrons in the outermost shell, the element tends to lose all 3 to achieve the stable configuration of the previous noble gas (neon: 2, 8). Losing 3 electrons gives a charge of +3. It is energetically easier to lose 3 electrons than to gain 5.

questions.question_text: Which of the following was a conclusion of Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment?

options.text: Electrons are embedded in a positive sphere
The atom has a small, dense, positively charged nucleus at its centre
Electrons revolve in fixed energy levels

questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford concluded that the atom has a very small, extremely dense, positively charged centre called the nucleus, which contains most of the mass. The rest of the atom is mostly empty space through which electrons move. This was the nuclear model of the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is Thomson's model (disproved by Rutherford). Option C is Bohr's contribution (came after Rutherford). Option D is Dalton's postulate. Rutherford's key conclusion was the existence of a tiny, dense, positive nucleus at the centre of the atom.

questions.question_text: An electron has a negative charge and a proton has a positive charge of equal magnitude.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. An electron carries a negative charge of -1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs, and a proton carries a positive charge of +1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs. The magnitudes are equal but the signs are opposite. This is why atoms with equal numbers of protons and electrons are electrically neutral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The charges on an electron (-1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) and proton (+1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C) are equal in magnitude but opposite in sign. This equal and opposite charge allows atoms to be neutral when they have equal numbers of protons and electrons.

questions.question_text: In Thomson's model of the atom, the positive charge is concentrated at the centre.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In Thomson's plum pudding model, the positive charge is uniformly distributed throughout the entire volume of the atom — NOT concentrated at the centre. It was Rutherford's model that placed the positive charge concentrated in a tiny nucleus at the centre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Thomson proposed that positive charge is spread uniformly throughout the atom like a pudding, with electrons embedded in it like plums. The idea of positive charge being concentrated at the centre came from Rutherford's nuclear model.

questions.question_text: The outermost shell of an atom can hold a maximum of 18 electrons.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. The outermost shell of an atom can hold a maximum of 8 electrons, regardless of the shell number. While the M shell can theoretically hold 2(3²) = 18 electrons, when it is the outermost shell, it holds a maximum of 8 electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Although the formula 2n² gives 18 for the M shell, the outermost shell can hold a maximum of only 8 electrons. This is the octet rule. A shell can hold more than 8 electrons only if it is not the outermost shell.

questions.question_text: Isotopes of the same element have the same number of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Isotopes are atoms of the same element that have the same number of protons (atomic number) but different numbers of neutrons, resulting in different mass numbers. For example, Carbon-12 has 6 neutrons and Carbon-14 has 8 neutrons, but both have 6 protons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. By definition, isotopes have the same atomic number (same protons) but different mass numbers (different neutrons). They belong to the same element because the identity of an element is determined by its number of protons.

questions.question_text: The average atomic mass of chlorine is 35.5 u because it exists as a mixture of two isotopes: Cl-35 and Cl-37.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Chlorine exists as two isotopes: Cl-35 (75% abundance) and Cl-37 (25% abundance). The average atomic mass = (35 × 0.75) + (37 × 0.25) = 26.25 + 9.25 = 35.5 u. This is why the atomic mass of chlorine is reported as 35.5 u, not a whole number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The atomic mass listed in the periodic table is a weighted average of all naturally occurring isotopes. For chlorine: (35 × 75/100) + (37 × 25/100) = 35.5 u. This explains why many elements have non-integer atomic masses.

questions.question_text: The mass of an atom is concentrated in its nucleus because protons and neutrons are much heavier than electrons.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. Protons and neutrons each have a mass of approximately 1 u, while an electron has a mass of only about 1/1836 u. Since the nucleus contains all protons and neutrons, virtually all the mass of an atom is concentrated in its tiny nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Each proton and neutron has a mass of about 1 u, while an electron has only about 1/1836 u. The nucleus (containing protons and neutrons) therefore accounts for more than 99.97% of the atom's mass, despite occupying a tiny fraction of the atom's volume.

questions.question_text: The subatomic particle with no electric charge is called a ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The neutron is the electrically neutral subatomic particle found in the nucleus. It was discovered by James Chadwick in 1932. Neutrons have a mass approximately equal to that of a proton (about 1 u) but carry no charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'neutron'. Of the three subatomic particles, the proton is positive, the electron is negative, and the neutron is neutral (no charge). Neutrons are located in the nucleus along with protons.

questions.question_text: Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment used a thin foil of ___ metal.
questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford used a very thin gold foil (about 1000 atoms thick) in his experiment. Gold was chosen because it is the most malleable metal and can be beaten into extremely thin sheets, allowing alpha particles to pass through.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'gold'. Gold was selected because it is extremely malleable and can be made into a foil just a few hundred nanometres thick. This thin foil allowed the experiment to reveal the internal structure of atoms.

questions.question_text: The maximum number of electrons that can be accommodated in the nth shell is given by the formula ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The maximum number of electrons in the nth shell is 2n², where n is the shell number (1, 2, 3, 4...). This gives: K shell (n=1) = 2, L shell (n=2) = 8, M shell (n=3) = 18, N shell (n=4) = 32.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is '2n^2' (2n squared). This formula gives the maximum electron capacity for each shell. However, the outermost shell can hold a maximum of 8 electrons regardless of the shell number.

questions.question_text: Atoms of different elements that have the same mass number but different atomic numbers are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Isobars are atoms of different elements that have the same mass number (A) but different atomic numbers (Z). For example, Calcium-40 (Z=20) and Argon-40 (Z=18) are isobars. They are different elements with different chemical properties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'isobars'. Isobars have the same mass number but different atomic numbers (different elements). This is different from isotopes, which have the same atomic number but different mass numbers (same element).

questions.question_text: The electrons in the outermost shell of an atom are called ___ electrons, and they determine the chemical properties of the element.
questions.explanation_correct: Valence electrons are the electrons present in the outermost shell of an atom. They participate in chemical bonding and determine the chemical properties and valency of an element. Elements with the same number of valence electrons show similar chemical behaviour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'valence'. Valence electrons are the outermost shell electrons that are involved in chemical reactions and bonding. The number of valence electrons determines how an element will combine with other elements.

questions.question_text: The key limitation of Rutherford's model was its inability to explain the ___ of the atom.
questions.explanation_correct: The major limitation of Rutherford's model was that it could not explain the stability of the atom. According to classical electromagnetic theory, an electron revolving around the nucleus should continuously lose energy and eventually spiral into the nucleus. Rutherford's model had no mechanism to prevent this collapse.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'stability'. Rutherford could not explain why electrons do not spiral into the nucleus while revolving around it, as classical physics predicts they should continuously radiate energy. Bohr addressed this by introducing the concept of fixed energy levels.

questions.question_text: The electronic configuration of an element is 2, 8, 6. The element is most likely to:
questions.explanation_correct: With 6 valence electrons, the element needs only 2 more electrons to complete its octet (8 electrons in the outermost shell). It is easier to gain 2 electrons than to lose 6, so the element tends to gain 2 electrons to form a -2 ion. This element is sulphur.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the number of valence electrons is more than 4, the element tends to gain electrons to complete its octet rather than lose them. With 6 valence electrons, gaining 2 is much easier than losing 6. The element forms a 2- anion.

questions.question_text: An isotope of iodine (I-131) is used in:
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine-131 is a radioactive isotope used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid disorders. The thyroid gland naturally absorbs iodine, so radioactive I-131 can be used to destroy overactive thyroid cells or detect thyroid problems.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I-131 is specifically used in treating thyroid disorders because the thyroid gland absorbs iodine. Other important isotope applications: U-235 in nuclear power, Co-60 in cancer treatment, and C-14 in carbon dating.

questions.question_text: An atom X has 12 protons and 12 neutrons. An atom Y has 12 protons and 14 neutrons. X and Y are:
questions.explanation_correct: Both X and Y have 12 protons (same atomic number), so they are the same element (magnesium). However, they have different numbers of neutrons (12 and 14), giving them different mass numbers (24 and 26). Atoms of the same element with different mass numbers are isotopes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since both have the same number of protons (12), they are the same element. Different neutron counts (12 vs 14) give different mass numbers (24 vs 26). This is the definition of isotopes: same atomic number, different mass numbers.

questions.question_text: An element has atomic number 19. Its electronic configuration and valency are:
questions.explanation_correct: Atomic number 19 means 19 electrons. Distribution: K=2, L=8, M=8 (outermost shell holds max 8), N=1. Configuration is 2, 8, 8, 1. With 1 valence electron, the valency is 1. This element is potassium (K).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 19 electrons are distributed as 2, 8, 8, 1 (not 2, 8, 9 because the outermost shell can hold max 8). With 1 electron in the outermost shell, the valency is 1. This is potassium, which loses 1 electron to form K⁺ ion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly compares the three subatomic particles?

options.text: Proton: +1 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus; Electron: -1 charge, ~1 u mass, in shells; Neutron: 0 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus
Proton: +1 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus; Electron: -1 charge, ~1/1836 u mass, in shells; Neutron: 0 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus
Proton: -1 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus; Electron: +1 charge, ~1/1836 u mass, in shells; Neutron: 0 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus
Proton: +1 charge, ~1/1836 u mass, in shells; Electron: -1 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus; Neutron: 0 charge, ~1 u mass, in nucleus

questions.explanation_correct: The correct comparison is: Proton has +1 charge, approximately 1 u mass, and is located in the nucleus. Electron has -1 charge, approximately 1/1836 u mass, and revolves in shells around the nucleus. Neutron has 0 charge, approximately 1 u mass, and is located in the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protons are positive (not negative) with mass ~1 u in the nucleus. Electrons are negative (not positive) with much smaller mass (~1/1836 u) in shells around the nucleus. Neutrons are neutral with mass ~1 u in the nucleus. Only option B correctly lists all three properties for all three particles.

questions.question_text: How does Thomson's plum pudding model differ from Rutherford's nuclear model in terms of the distribution of positive charge?

options.text: Both models have positive charge concentrated in the centre
Thomson proposed positive charge is uniformly spread throughout the atom, while Rutherford proposed it is concentrated in a tiny, dense nucleus at the centre
Thomson placed positive charge in the nucleus while Rutherford spread it throughout

questions.explanation_correct: In Thomson's plum pudding model, the positive charge is distributed uniformly throughout the entire volume of the atom, with electrons embedded in it. Rutherford's experiment proved this wrong and established that the positive charge is concentrated in a very small, dense nucleus at the centre of the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is wrong because only Rutherford's model has charge in the centre. Option C reverses the two models. Both models do discuss positive charge (D). Thomson spread it uniformly; Rutherford concentrated it in the nucleus (B).

questions.question_text: How do isotopes differ from isobars in terms of atomic number and mass number?

options.text: Isotopes have the same mass number but different atomic numbers; isobars have the same atomic number but different mass numbers
Isotopes have the same atomic number but different mass numbers; isobars have the same mass number but different atomic numbers
Both isotopes and isobars have the same atomic number
Both isotopes and isobars have the same mass number

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with the same atomic number (Z) but different mass numbers (A) due to different numbers of neutrons. For example, C-12 and C-14. Isobars are atoms of different elements with the same mass number (A) but different atomic numbers (Z). For example, Ca-40 and Ar-40.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the definitions. Isotopes and isobars do not both share the same atomic number (C) or the same mass number (D). Isotopes share atomic number but differ in mass number; isobars share mass number but differ in atomic number (B).

questions.question_text: How does Bohr's model improve upon Rutherford's model of the atom?

options.text: Bohr discovered the nucleus, which Rutherford did not know about
Bohr proposed that electrons revolve in discrete energy levels (shells) where they do not radiate energy, solving Rutherford's stability problem
Bohr removed the concept of the nucleus from the atomic model
Bohr proposed that electrons are embedded in a positive sphere

questions.explanation_correct: Rutherford's model could not explain why revolving electrons do not lose energy and spiral into the nucleus. Bohr resolved this by proposing that electrons move only in specific, discrete energy levels (shells) and do not radiate energy while in these orbits. Electrons only gain or lose energy when jumping between shells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rutherford discovered the nucleus, not Bohr (A). Bohr kept the nucleus concept from Rutherford (C). Electrons embedded in a positive sphere was Thomson's model (D). Bohr's key improvement was introducing fixed energy levels to explain atomic stability (B).

questions.question_text: How does the mass of a proton compare to the mass of an electron?

options.text: A proton is about 1836 times heavier than an electron
An electron is heavier than a proton
A proton has no mass while an electron has mass

questions.explanation_correct: A proton has a mass of approximately 1 u (atomic mass unit), while an electron has a mass of approximately 1/1836 u. This means a proton is about 1836 times heavier than an electron. This is why the mass of an atom is essentially determined by its protons and neutrons in the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Their masses are not equal (A). An electron is much lighter, not heavier (C). Both particles have mass (D). A proton is approximately 1836 times more massive than an electron (B).

questions.question_text: How does the chemical behaviour of sodium (2, 8, 1) differ from that of chlorine (2, 8, 7) in terms of electron transfer?

options.text: Both lose electrons to form positive ions
Sodium tends to lose 1 electron to form Na+ while chlorine tends to gain 1 electron to form Cl-, because each achieves a stable octet this way
Both gain electrons to form negative ions
Sodium gains 7 electrons while chlorine loses 1 electron

questions.explanation_correct: Sodium has 1 valence electron and finds it easier to lose it to achieve the stable configuration of neon (2, 8), forming Na+. Chlorine has 7 valence electrons and finds it easier to gain 1 electron to complete its octet (2, 8, 8), forming Cl-. Their opposite tendencies explain why NaCl forms by electron transfer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: They do not both lose electrons (A) or both gain electrons (C). Sodium losing 1 is easier than gaining 7; chlorine gaining 1 is easier than losing 7 (D is reversed). Sodium loses and chlorine gains electrons to achieve stability (B).

questions.question_text: A subatomic particle has approximately 1 u mass, carries a positive charge, and is found inside the nucleus. This particle is a:
questions.explanation_correct: The described properties — approximately 1 u mass, positive charge, and location inside the nucleus — uniquely identify a proton. Electrons are negatively charged and found in shells. Neutrons have no charge. Alpha particles are not individual subatomic particles but consist of 2 protons and 2 neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons (A) are negative and found in shells, not the nucleus. Neutrons (B) have no charge. Alpha particles (D) are composed of 2 protons and 2 neutrons. A positively charged particle of ~1 u mass in the nucleus is a proton (C).

questions.question_text: An element has electronic configuration 2, 8, 8, 2. It has low ionisation energy and tends to lose electrons easily. This element is most likely a:
questions.explanation_correct: The configuration 2, 8, 8, 2 with 2 valence electrons and a tendency to lose electrons easily are characteristic features of a metal. This is calcium (atomic number 20), which loses 2 electrons to form Ca2+ ion and achieve a stable octet. Metals typically have 1-3 valence electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Noble gases (A) have complete octets and do not lose electrons. Non-metals (B) tend to gain electrons. Metalloids (D) show intermediate behaviour. An element with 2 valence electrons that easily loses them is a metal (C).

questions.question_text: Two atoms have the same mass number (40) but different atomic numbers (20 and 18). These atoms are examples of:
questions.explanation_correct: Atoms with the same mass number but different atomic numbers are called isobars. In this case, Ca-40 (Z=20) and Ar-40 (Z=18) are isobars. They are different elements that happen to have the same total number of protons and neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes (A) have the same atomic number but different mass numbers. Isotones (C) have the same number of neutrons. Allotropes (D) are different structural forms of the same element. Atoms with the same mass number but different atomic numbers are isobars (B).

questions.question_text: In an experiment, a beam of positively charged particles is directed at a thin metal foil. Most particles pass through undeflected, a few are deflected, and very few bounce back. This experiment is:
questions.explanation_correct: The described observations — most particles passing through, few deflecting, and very few bouncing back — are the hallmark results of Rutherford's alpha particle scattering experiment using gold foil. These results led to the discovery of the nucleus and the nuclear model of the atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thomson's experiment (A) used cathode rays (electrons), not positively charged particles. Chadwick (B) bombarded beryllium with alpha particles to find neutrons. Bohr (D) studied atomic spectra. The described gold foil experiment with alpha particles is Rutherford's (C).

questions.question_text: Riya is solving a chemistry problem in class. She is asked to find the number of electrons in each shell for an element with atomic number 16. What electronic configuration should Riya write?
questions.explanation_correct: For atomic number 16 (sulphur), there are 16 electrons. Filling shells from innermost: K shell = 2 (maximum for n=1), L shell = 8 (maximum for n=2), M shell = 16 - 2 - 8 = 6. So Riya should write 2, 8, 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 2, 14 (A) is wrong because L shell can hold only 8, not 14. 8, 8 (C) ignores that K shell fills first with only 2. 2, 6, 8 (D) has the wrong filling order. The correct configuration is 2, 8, 6 (B), filling each shell to its maximum before moving to the next.

questions.question_text: Amit reads in his textbook that the atomic mass of chlorine is 35.5 u, not a whole number. His teacher asks him to explain why. Which explanation should Amit give?

options.text: Chlorine atoms are broken into halves in nature
Chlorine exists as two isotopes, Cl-35 (75%) and Cl-37 (25%), and 35.5 is the weighted average of their masses
Chlorine has half a neutron in its nucleus
The mass number of chlorine is exactly 35.5

questions.explanation_correct: Chlorine exists naturally as a mixture of two isotopes: Cl-35 (about 75% abundance) and Cl-37 (about 25% abundance). The atomic mass 35.5 is a weighted average: (35 x 0.75) + (37 x 0.25) = 26.25 + 9.25 = 35.5 u. Individual atoms always have whole-number mass numbers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atoms cannot be split into halves (A). There is no such thing as half a neutron (C). Mass number is always a whole number for each atom; 35.5 is an average (D). The non-integer atomic mass arises from the weighted average of two isotopes (B).

questions.question_text: Priya is watching a documentary about Rutherford's experiment. She sees that out of 20,000 alpha particles fired at a gold foil, only about 1 bounced back. What should Priya conclude from this observation?

options.text: Most of the atom is solid matter
The gold foil has large holes in it
The nucleus is extremely small compared to the overall size of the atom, so most alpha particles pass through empty space
Alpha particles are too small to interact with atoms

questions.explanation_correct: The fact that only about 1 in 20,000 alpha particles bounced back means only a tiny fraction encountered the nucleus head-on. This proves the nucleus occupies an extremely small volume compared to the whole atom. The rest of the atom is empty space through which alpha particles pass unimpeded.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the atom were mostly solid (A), most particles would bounce back. The gold foil has no visible holes (B). Alpha particles can and do interact with the nucleus (D). The observation proves the nucleus is tiny and the atom is mostly empty space (C).

questions.question_text: Arjun is given an atom with 15 protons, 16 neutrons, and 15 electrons. His teacher asks him to find the atomic number and mass number. What are the correct values?
questions.explanation_correct: Atomic number (Z) = number of protons = 15. Mass number (A) = protons + neutrons = 15 + 16 = 31. Electrons are not included in mass number because their mass is negligible. This atom is phosphorus-31.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Atomic number equals protons (15), not neutrons (A). Mass number = protons + neutrons = 31, not protons + neutrons + electrons (D). Option C reverses the values. Atomic number = 15, mass number = 31 (B).

questions.question_text: Meera's teacher writes an electronic configuration 2, 8, 2 on the board and asks the class what valency this element would have and whether it would gain or lose electrons. What is the correct answer?

options.text: Valency 2, it would lose 2 electrons to achieve a stable octet
Valency 8, it would neither gain nor lose electrons

questions.explanation_correct: The element has 2 valence electrons (in the outermost shell). Since 2 is less than 4, the element would prefer to lose these 2 electrons rather than gain 6 to complete an octet. After losing 2 electrons, its configuration becomes 2, 8 (like neon), which is stable. This element is magnesium (atomic number 12) with valency 2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The element would lose, not gain, electrons since it has only 2 valence electrons (A). The valency is 2, not 6 (B). The outermost shell has 2 electrons, so the valency is 2, not 8 (D). It loses 2 electrons to achieve the stable neon configuration (C).

questions.question_text: A student claims that the M shell can always hold a maximum of 18 electrons based on the formula 2n^2. Why is this not entirely correct?

options.text: Because the formula 2n^2 is wrong for all shells
Because although 2n^2 gives 18 for the M shell, when M is the outermost shell it can hold only a maximum of 8 electrons
Because the M shell does not exist in any atom
Because the M shell can hold a maximum of 32 electrons

questions.explanation_correct: The formula 2n^2 gives the theoretical maximum capacity of a shell (18 for M shell where n=3). However, there is an important rule: the outermost shell of an atom can hold a maximum of only 8 electrons. So when M is the outermost shell, it holds at most 8, not 18. It can hold more than 8 only when it is an inner shell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula 2n^2 is correct for calculating shell capacity (A). The M shell does exist (C). The N shell, not M shell, can hold 32 (D). The limitation is that the outermost shell holds a maximum of 8, even though 2n^2 gives 18 for M shell (B).

questions.question_text: A student says that isotopes of an element have different physical and chemical properties. Which part of this statement is incorrect?

options.text: The physical properties part is incorrect — isotopes have the same physical properties
The chemical properties part is incorrect — isotopes have identical chemical properties because they have the same electronic configuration

questions.explanation_correct: Isotopes do have different physical properties (like mass, density, and rate of diffusion) because they have different numbers of neutrons and hence different masses. However, their chemical properties are identical because chemical behaviour depends on the number and arrangement of electrons, which is the same for all isotopes of an element.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Isotopes do have different physical properties (A is wrong about this). Not both parts are incorrect (C). Not both parts are correct because chemical properties are identical (D). The error is in claiming different chemical properties — isotopes have the same chemical properties (B).

questions.question_text: Some students think that Rutherford's experiment proved Thomson's model completely wrong in every aspect. Why is this an oversimplification?

options.text: Because Thomson's model was actually correct all along

Because Thomson was correct that the atom contains both positive and negative charges, and that the overall atom is electrically neutral — what was disproved was the uniform distribution of positive charge
Because Rutherford's experiment confirmed Thomson's model
Because neither Thomson nor Rutherford made any valid observations

questions.explanation_correct: Thomson was correct about several things: atoms contain negatively charged electrons, atoms contain positive charge, and atoms are overall electrically neutral. What Rutherford disproved was specifically the distribution of positive charge — it is not spread uniformly throughout the atom but concentrated in a tiny, dense nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thomson's model was not entirely correct (A). Rutherford did not confirm Thomson's model — he disproved the positive charge distribution (C). Both scientists made significant valid contributions (D). Thomson got the charge composition right but the charge distribution wrong (B).

questions.question_text: Why did the alpha particles that bounced back at nearly 180° in Rutherford's experiment do so, rather than passing through?

options.text: Because they hit the electrons in the atom

Because they collided head-on with the tiny, dense, positively charged nucleus, and the strong electrostatic repulsion between the positive alpha particle and positive nucleus reversed their direction
Because the gold foil was too thick for them to pass through
Because alpha particles have no charge and were reflected by the surface

questions.explanation_correct: Alpha particles carry a +2 charge. When an alpha particle approaches the positively charged nucleus head-on, both positive charges repel each other. Since the nucleus is extremely dense and massive compared to the alpha particle, the strong electrostatic repulsion reverses the alpha particle's direction completely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons are too light to deflect the much heavier alpha particles (A). The gold foil was extremely thin (C). Alpha particles carry a positive (+2) charge, not zero charge (D). The bounce-back occurs due to strong electrostatic repulsion between the positive alpha particle and the positive nucleus (B).

questions.question_text: Why do elements with completely filled outermost shells (like neon with configuration 2, 8) show very low chemical reactivity?

options.text: Because they have too many protons in the nucleus
Because their completely filled outermost shell is a very stable configuration, so they have no tendency to gain, lose, or share electrons
Because they have no electrons at all
Because they are always found as liquids at room temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Noble gases like neon (2, 8) have completely filled outermost shells, which is an extremely stable electronic configuration. Since they already have the maximum number of electrons in their outermost shell, they have no tendency to gain, lose, or share electrons with other atoms, making them chemically inert.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical reactivity depends on electron configuration, not proton count (A). Noble gases do have electrons (C). Noble gases are actually all gases at room temperature (D). Their low reactivity is due to the stability of their complete outermost shell (B).

questions.question_text: Why is the mass of an electron not included when calculating the mass number of an atom?

options.text: Because electrons are not part of the atom
Because the mass of an electron (about 1/1836 u) is negligibly small compared to the mass of a proton or neutron (about 1 u each), so it barely affects the total mass
Because electrons have no mass at all
Because electrons are always equal in number to protons and cancel out

questions.explanation_correct: The mass of an electron is approximately 1/1836 u, which is negligibly small compared to the mass of a proton or neutron (each approximately 1 u). Even in atoms with many electrons, their combined mass contributes less than 0.05% of the atom's total mass. Hence, mass number considers only protons and neutrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons are part of the atom (A). Electrons do have mass, just very little (C). The number of electrons equalling protons is about charge neutrality, not mass cancellation (D). Electron mass is excluded because it is negligibly small — about 1/1836 of a proton's mass (B).
